text: Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds) Doctor: A little bit. No bumps at all up here. No pain, no itching. Patient: No. I noticed some weakness in my right leg. Doctor: They drew blood today. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Last week? Patient: Last week, yes, and my PSA jumped up tremendously. This is from last year. This is December and this is last week – up point five. Doctor: Blood count is good, tab - nothing dramatic – sporadic just below the normal range. So your kidney function goes up and down. So two months hundred at one point six, then it was repeated back down to one and then it was up at one point five. Where did you have your scan last week? Patient: In Hospital A in B___. I have the information and phone number. Doctor: So is G___ a new doctor for you or have you seen him for a while? Patient: No, that was only the second visit. And I saw him after, thoracic surgeon in Hospital B and spotted through tests, prostate cancer cells in my liver, and also on my lung Family Member: December. Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem.

text: Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So that drug, uh, would be another possible option, because it’s a, it’s an approved drug. I tend to use it in men who have more pain. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Have, you know, multiple bone spots. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, right now, we’re doing a trial where we’re giving that drug in combination with a vaccine. The vaccine is called, sipuleucel-T. And that’s the only vaccine we have for any cancer. Both drugs together have shown that they can improve, uh, how long men live with, from prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the idea is if we combine them together, would they work together? And there’s some evidence that radiation makes the immune system work better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So the complicating part about that study is that the vaccine, you know, is a little involved. You have to go to the Red Cross. They’ve got to call some, they have to kind of hook you up to a machine that kind of pass your blood through and pull out the, the cells that they’re going to make the vaccine out of. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And so it’s, it’s, you know, you’ve got to do a little bit of work to get the vaccine. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And add either chemo or add a hormone drug to it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that would be what we would talk about. Doctor: So how, you know, one is sort of yet such small disease that we're going to try to manage it without using a traditional method, versus we think you've got so much disease that we're going to throw the kitchen sink at you, right? Wow. Okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, that is why. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The Aximun scan may help and may also confuse thing. Patient: Mhm. text: Patient: Exactly. Doctor: So you know radiation is tough. It helps the pain but it’s always something for something, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: not something for nothing, so there’s some side effects there. And you got a lot of radiation. Patient: So the question there being then probably safe to go back on the supplements? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you. Doctor: Yes. I agree with you. Patient: And I also had a question about that proton treatment that they have in B___. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Um Doctor: Not ah truly applicable to you at this point. That’s great for if you were just newly diagnosed with your prostate cancer or if you have some specific area on your spine. You obviously just got the radiation to there but if you know you’re a baby, for example, and you had a really tiny spinal cord, and you have this cancer next to it, a proton would be the perfect treatment. For adults, it’s a little harder to know what is better than the standard. So you know you hope maybe if you got protons you wouldn’t have had so many side effects. That’s possible. But it’s not as mainstream I think as we’d like to see it. At some point now when they’re really up and running and more patients will get experience, we’ll probably get a better sense of that. But for now I think you’ve got the best treatment which was those three areas in the spine and then your pelvis. Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-?

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You can’t actually see the lymph nodes when you remove them, you just see packets of fat. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Just lumps of fat and the lymph nodes are imbedded in the fat and the pathologist has to find them. Family Member: Oh gosh. Okay. Doctor: So we always go to the same area so we remove these packets of fat from that area along the pelvic side wall, it’s along the iliac arteries. Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Okay. And uh oh one more question. Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Now with these injections, G____ said he won’t be able to have an erection or any of that. Is that even with like using you talk about using Viagra or something else before, even with that you can’t? Doctor: Uh well you could try. There’s no harm in trying. Uh sometimes they depress your drive, your libido, you desire, and so most men just don’t care that much. There’s some men who do care but no matter what you do you can’t knock their drive down. Doctor: And if that’s the case, you can, you can do injection treatments. Did he mention that?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
